job_title: Graphic Designer in Iowa City, IA
pros: -The benefits relative to other US companies is far above average. Family and friends who have greater pay than me have far worse and far more expensive healthcare. Their yearly PTO pales in comparison as well. - Even when you're busy, overtime is never expected. After 5pm my day is done nearly 100% of the time. Work-life balance is respected if you're not a senior leader. - Hybrid and remote is respected depending on job location and role
cons: - The pay is below average for how much work is expected of you. Do not expect pay increases greater than 2% per year. There are years where you'll receive 1% or less. - Your job will accumulate more responsibilities than what you're being paid for. - The pay disparity between most employees and senior staff/directors is massive. Expect to make less than $60k/yr as a senior employee with 1% raises every year while your boss makes well over $125k. - If you're looking for career advancement, this is not the place for you. Promotions do not happen here. - The majority of staff are over 45 years old. If you're young, expect to be in a very small minority and thus, not taken as seriously as older employees. - A lot of work seems to be generated for the sake of it. People at the UI are rewarded for looking busy by contributing work that has very little value - Iowa is now controlled by a far-right, anti-education conservative legislature. Do not expect raises or budgets, and I would go so far as to say everyone should always be worried about the next budget from the Board of Regents and how it will be interpreted by the shot-callers at the university.

pros: Great healthcare. Good sick time. They have to accept call ins without question due to the Union I think. I’ve never been written up but near as I can tell it’s almost impossible to get fired from this place. I like my coworkers the college kids in particular. Most of the nurses are friendly.
cons: I started in 2020 making 14.25 an hour and will finished in 2023 making 15.42 an hour. I get paid the same after almost 3 years of experience as the brand new people with zero experience. When I’ve asked for a raise they say “we can’t because you have a union”. I doubt my union is limiting my pay. I should mention I’ve had 2 good annual performance reviews. Expect the bare minimum where pay is concerned. I make 2500 a month but only see 1600 of it. Parking is 20$ for an 8 hour shift. If you’re young and need cash this isn’t it. Transferring within the university is possible but extremely slow. Think 4 months minimum. I had no luck getting from NA to lab tech.

pros: I went to school here, worked here, left, and then came back. There have been changes, but this place is really trying. The benefits are exceptional and work-life balance is second-to-none. Salaries are competitive within the higher education space. Due to budget cuts and decreases in state appropriations, there has been some belt-tightening, but I give UI credit for continuing to push growth in areas that make sense and create jobs even if the forecasted demand is down the road.
cons: There's not a lot of room for advancement in many departments. The structure is fairly rigid, and usually promotions happen when someone leaves for whatever reason. Athletics, especially football, is huge here. Home football game days are a nightmare to navigate if you live in town, but the money brought to Iowa City and Coralville is welcome. Just stay inside like I do.

pros: Good benefits. Stable employment. Safe.
cons: The University of Iowa is essentially run by it's HR Department, a bunch of 26 year old MBAs who do not respect anyone with a real graduate degree, experience, or serious research. Administrative jobs here are so much easier and pay literally double what academic jobs do that I can't imagine why anyone would want to work so hard in grad school getting real PhD and then struggle through the tenure process when being an upper level administrative assistant for a dean or department head will earn you more or as much money and you really don't have to do anything but have a heartbeat and minor computer skills. The University of Iowa is a posterchild for the capture of formerly amazing research university by a bunch of moronic bureaucrats and management nitwits who don't know anything about science or research but are basically running the entire show. Major amateur hour, this is what happens when you let untalented MBAs with no vision and no real knowledge of the scientific method run a research institution. Diversity push was significant 5 years ago, but they have lost almost all of their major diversity hires in that time.

review_title: scary place to work - IIHR - pretend that you know and like your boss and move ahead
job_title: Engineer in Iowa City, IA
pros: Some reputation in Iowa. Some grads and under grads have a lot of potential  but may face a few opportunities to grow.
cons:
- Fake people.
- Lack of critical thinking
- A lot of upper level Professors and main researchers do not master all the concepts necessary to take advantage of workers with talent, well and spot research projects.
- The way to advance is just follow orders from people with little to no knowledge is really questionable.
- People from Iowa area gets preference over others. Even if they do not show a high level of competence. They cover their tracks so well that only been inside you can spot the real deal.
- Take advantage of cheap labor from talented graduate and undergrad students to make proposal cheap. So main PI's gets a lot of money and can pretend to know while the others just pass by, so they can hire a new batch of talented people.

review_title: Declining working conditions due to loss of public support
job_title: Professor in Iowa City, IA
pros:
Standout units in arts, health and engineering colleges regularly achieve national and international recognition which raise morale and pride in institutional prowess.
High standards and fair procedures evident in most departments that strive to make and retain very good or at least competent academic appointments.
Majority of professional colleges are ranked in upper half of nationally recognized public universities.
Despite managerial pressures, a degree of faculty and staff self-governance continuies to be mechanism to identify issues, vent distresss and prevent undue management-staff rancor.
Physical proximity of health colleges and research centers with liberal arts and science campus promotes interesting synergies in research and also social life.
Pleasant institutional placement in riverine landscape close to the commercial center of small city with urban amenities that appeal to both students and professional and academic staff.
cons:
Uninspired leadership is confused whether institution's main purpose is educational or economic-developmental as demanded by politicians.
Central administrators too cautiously navigate around  Republican state legislature's hostile attitude to liberal educational practices built over last century.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Iowa City, IA
pros: They have a decent Grad student union that had fought for many benefits, but they completely lack the understanding that STEM students are like humanities students. The Graduate School is finally coming around to the concept that there is more to life with a PhD than academia. This may be due to pressure from funding sources. Over all it was a good experience and I would recommend Iowa to anyone.
cons: Pay. Grad students need better pay. This "you're doing it for the love of academia" is BS. Also, they really need to monitor the working conditions and hours of students. Most of us do work hard and there's no 40 work week in grad school especially if you are a STEM, BUT some profs over work their students expecting them to perform duties not related to their grad studies and then still live in the lab 24/7/365. That's not good for the students. Balance is necessary.

review_title: Opportunities for learning and professional growth are abundant at the University of Iowa
job_title: Administrative Services Coordinator in Iowa City, IA
pros: As the major public sector employer in Iowa City and surrounding areas, the UI has much to offer: generally good pay and benefits, and many internal job opportunities.
cons: I've been at the UI for over 30 years, first as a student and now as an employee.  It saddens me that this venerable public institution has suffered massive losses in funding from the state (like so many universities across the country) and, as a consequence, is now forced to pursue fundraising and corporate strategies at an ever more frantic pace in order to support every new initiative and even maintain a fast-eroding base of core educational programs and services.

review_title: Pomerantz, a great place to intern!
job_title: Career Advisor in Iowa City, IA
pros: Working at The University of Iowa's Pomerantz Career Center will enable you to not only help other students acheive their career goals, but it will also help you in your journey towards career success, now and in the future. The faculty staff at Pomerantz Career Center are very personable, approachable and genuinely helpful. You go into work everyday knowing that you are a valued part of the work community. The overall envirnoment is very laid back and you do not feel that you are unable to express yourself or your concerns in regards to your positon and/or personal life. Overall this is a great office to work at!
cons: The only downsides of this internship would be the inablity to go on full-time after the internship is complete. The general idea is that the internship stands alone and is its own entity that will help you in your future career endeavors, however, it will not make a possible opportunity to work at the Pomerantz Career Center full time.

review_title: Not good at an institutional level for postdocs
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Iowa City, IA
pros:
Low cost of living
Many well-respected departments 
Excellent core facilities and library
Opportunities to advance to Assistant Research Scientist
cons:
Institution barely recognizes postdocs.
Benefits are minimal: health insurance is personal only, not family and paid time off that doesn't rollover like it does for employees
Benefits aren't clearly communicated since the benefit office is confused about what a postdoc is and won't give info out routinely since "most postdocs are foreign anyway"
Large bureaucracy for submitting grants
Parking is difficult and postdocs don't qualify to get on a parking list

job_title: Academic Advisor in Iowa City, IA
pros: Everyone that I met at Iowa was friendly, welcoming and helpful. I felt cared for. People were always dropping by my office to see how I was doing and to provide suggestions for me. Also, they would have great office parties and food--it felt like a family. The students were also pleasant to work with, and I looked forward to my job every day. The most stress-free job I've had yet! Also, the benefits are amazing, and the schedule of an advisor is very flexible.
cons: Not a lot of room for growth in this particular job. Yes, I might have been able to teach a college transition course here or there, and I got involved with the National Academic Advising Association to write reviews and help peer edit monographs, but there didn't seem to be many opportunities for growth in my department. It wasn't a job that I could see myself doing for more than four or five years.

review_title: Great place to have a career at!
job_title: in Iowa City, IA
pros: Flexible work arrangements, OUTSTANDING benefits, good pay, standing desks (at least in my dept), tuition and child care assistance, reimbursement for gym fees (if you use the on campus gym at least 4x a month), generous vacation and sick leave, great commitment to diversity and inclusion, lots of PD opportunities for professional and scientific staff, lots of opportunities to move up and areas to move around to. Fantastic wellness and EAP programs!
cons: Lots of red tape to get anything done.

job_title: Administrative Services Coordinator in Iowa City, IA
pros: I love working here. Everyone is so friendly! The work is rewarding as I regularly work with students, faculty, and staff. The benefits are really solid, speaking from a Professional and Scientific staff member standpoint. Depending on where you work, dress code can be casual or business professional. The work/life balance is great. They really want you to be able to spend time with your family, which I greatly value.
cons: The only con I can think of is that it can be a little hard to move up in the ranks, but even then, I'm really happy where I'm at so I've never had to work for a promotion or anything. The salaries can also be a little low but they make up for the salary with their investment in great benefits.

review_title: A wonderful experience of learning and growth.
job_title: Web Developer in Iowa City, IA
pros: Good pay as a student, exposure to practically every field you'd ever be interested, and opportunities to support you. I learned a ton of invaluable skills in interpersonal interaction, coding, and instructing customers. I got to travel as well. Compensation is about what you'd expect for a student part-time job. Iowa City is wonderful.
cons: Some of the bosses I had here seemed a little to complacent with how things were, and not how they could be better. You don't have much say in a lot of what happens round the office. Nepotism is rampant. My boss was a little incompetent at returning basic emails, and was very passive aggressive in his communication.

job_title: Research Assistant in Iowa City, IA
pros:
Coverage of insurance provided by the university is not bad
University has its own hospital (actually half of the university is hospital)
cons:
You have to pay around $160 as a student if you are not employed for the insurance
If you want to make your spouse insured, it becomes $760 in total for both of you (for non employement)
Even if you are employed by the university (TA or RA), you still have to pay around $250 to include your spouse in insurance
What you'd get after tax (excluding insurance) would be around $1500, and you still have to pay for the rent which is around $750
(This applies to some departments such as Computer Science which can't make money unfortunately. Some rich departments may pay more)

review_title: I've only worked as a TA in the Computer Science department, but overall I've had no major complaints.
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Iowa City, IA
pros: It completely depends on which professor you are teamed with, but my experiences have been generally positive so far. The amount of work is appropriate, and they are as accommodating as possible with schedules.
cons: The only real problems I've had have been related to miscommunication between professors and students on assignments. I have nothing negative to say about the work environment besides the fact that many of us did not have real offices due to space constraints, which for me is more of a minor inconvenience since I prefer to work at a coffee house, anyway. Oh, and TA assignments are rarely settled more than a couple weeks ahead of the semester's start--at least I knew that I would have one, just not which class.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Iowa City, IA
pros: Research Assistantship is a great way to get financially supported by one's PI while in graduate school. Healthcare benefits and tuition benefits (for out of state students, in particular) are great if you have half-time appointment as research assistant or teaching assistant.
cons: There is a significant variability in work load, quality of life, quality of managing, etc. depending on the PI. It is very difficult to know what they are like before committing to work for a lab.

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Iowa City, IA
pros: This is a large research university and is committed to doing the work. The sheer size of it means that almost any intellectual resource you are looking for is available on campus. Its just a matter of finding the right personnel to collaborate with.
cons: There is a lot of top down decision making that goes on and thus it suffers in terms of shred governance. It is a predominantly white institution that doesn't seem to quite understand that retaining people of color takes deliberate and intentional thinking and planning.

job_title: in Iowa City, IA
pros: The medical insurance is superb and you have access to the College of Dentistry for low cost care.  The Microbiology Department has good research benefits like a fully stocked biochem storeroom, an enzyme core and microscopy facility.  Because it is a college town going out for drinks is inexpensive, though the crowds can be rowdy.
cons: The weather in the winter is abysmal.  The town is on the small side and doesn't offer much in variety of food or experience.  The population of the people working at the University is almost homogenously Caucasian so there is not much diversity.  The nearest large city is Chicago at ~3 hours to the east.

job_title: Senior Associate in Iowa City, IA
pros: Great benefits,  cool co workers.
cons: I worked at UI for many years and have had a (mostly) great experience.  Unfortunately the university is reeling from a multi million dollar lawsuit/major budget cuts,  but my department continued to (somehow) pay faculty higher wages while stagnating the pay of the hard-working administrators.  The management in my office was truly awful- two bosses who hate each other and refuse to work together,  much to the detriment of the office.  They are unwilling to be innovative and keep up with industry standards.  Their team greatly suffered (and still does ) due to their unprofessionalism and incompetence.  This school is a sinking ship

review_title: It's a one-horse town - but the horse is pretty stable (at least for now).
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Iowa City, IA
pros: Iowa City is an excellent community with great opportunities to experience cultural and civic events without the hassle and expense of a major metropolitan area.
cons: There are politics and egos galore in academia.  I imagine it's like this everywhere.  It's not the best and the brightest who rise to the top, but the ballsiest, brawniest, and brassiest.  That can be disheartening to witness.

review_title: Great position at a great school
job_title: Resident Assistant in Iowa City, IA
pros: Put resident assistants through intense training to prepare them for the year.  Hire diverse employees.  Weekly one-on-one and group meetings with staff.  Continue training throughout the year.  First year students are fun to work with.  Learn how to become an effective leader.
cons: Constantly working (24/7).  Even if you are not on duty, residents can always knock on your door.  Training starts early so it is hard to have a job in the summer.  Many difficult situations to handle in the residence halls.  Limited nights to sleep out of the dorms.

review_title: A good state institution that needs refocused on students
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Iowa City, IA
pros: Well organized administration, graduate cohorts are appropriately sized, workload for teaching assistants is appropriate. Compensation is good for graduate assistants.  Departmental staff is professional and helpful.  Education/work balance is maintained at an appropriate level.
cons: Infantile faculty infighting, instructor focus on research rather than education, exorbitant and unnecessary fees for graduate students thanks to gullible undergraduate population.  Institution fails to assist foreign students whose English proficiency is typically insufficient to deal with lecture-based coursework.  Upper administration is hopelessly corrupt and intent on maintaining increasing revenues rather than student opportunities.

job_title: Student Systems Analyst in Iowa City, IA
pros: Great job for students, flexible hours, great co workers, and awesome experience. Got tons of hands on hardware experience as well as software configuration experience. Lastly gain some customer service skills while support university employees.
cons: The pay is not great, but not horrible either. A little bit over minimum wage. For a job that requires a decent skill set, it would be nice if you received better compensation. In the end it is a student job so cant knock them too hard for this. Also wish the full time staff would work more with the students to show them more of the advanced software tools to help increase our experience.

review_title: Nice place for families (good benefits) that are looking to settle down.
job_title: Helpdesk Consultant in Iowa City, IA
pros: The benefits are unmatched throughout the state of Iowa, especially in terms of health care. The coworkers in my department were very friendly and Iowa locals/ natives.  Most departments are easily accessible even without necessarily owning one's own car. Nice place to work with a small town feel.
cons: No real chances for improvement. Where you come in at is pretty much where you stay. You do get yearly raises, some based on performance but mostly based on presets by the bosses. Some of the bosses seemed somewhat out of touch with the technology. The nightlife is crowded with students who can sometimes be very immature.

review_title: Best hospital to work in Iowa
job_title: RN Staff Nurse in Iowa City, IA
pros:
-decent retirement 
-charge differential $1, preceptor differential $1
Evening shifts currently pay an extra $3 per hour.
Night shifts currently pay an extra $3.50 per hour.
Weekends currently pay an extra $2.50 
Differentials are combined 
No mandatory vacation use when over staffed
Since we are always short nurses it's an extra $15/hour when you pick up extra (not $10), + time and a half when you go past 40 hrs/week
Self schedule
Don't pay for health insurance
cons:
Parking costs a lot and is far away
Management is far removed to bedside 
Care more about patient satisfaction than nurse satisfaction
The more you make the less you're cared about

job_title: Instructor in Iowa City, IA
pros: Our health insurance benefits are great, and there is little oversight, which means I can be creative in the classroom. However, depending on who you are, this could be a con---students have little context from which to set expectations.
cons: The very scant oversight means that I often feel lost about requirements and best practices. I felt sort of abandoned as a first-time instructor, and pretty much winged it the whole time. It wasn't until the third semester teaching that I felt like I got the hang of it, which is deeply unfair to the students.

review_title: Great Supervisors, and very flexible to student schedule
job_title: Student Assistant in Iowa City, IA
pros: They have a very flexible schedule to work well with students and our strange work schedule. Its a great quite place to get some of your online work done.
cons:
Sometimes in order to get a good amount of hours you have to work over night or very early morning shifts.
Sometimes graduate students in the Library Science program don't contribute as much help as may be needed when at the service desk. Working in circulation has no windows and can be boring at time.

job_title: Research Assistant in Iowa City, IA
pros: Great health care and dental benefits, generous time off for vacation and sick time.  My manager was very lenient in allowing me to take vacation whenver I wanted to.  He also encouraged a strong work/life balance and kept in contact with the family members of all his workers. When I got sick, my coworkers sent me flowers. The University is focused on intellectual pursuits and academics.  All employees worked well together for the common good.
cons: Low pay since it is academia. I made a fraction of what I would have if I had chosen to work in the private sector.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Iowa City, IA
pros: Very intelligent people and high pace research in physics department. Most of the electronic and optical devices are new and competitive in the current market.
cons: It is in Iowa City and the IATL building next to the Iowa river. So there are some chance that the river can flood. However, in last couple years they have been working on this particular issue which is more promising than the previous setup of avoiding such natural effects.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Iowa City, IA
pros: Very good research environment. The University of Iowa and the Iowa Hospitals and Clinics together provide a great opportunity and environment for pre-clinical and clinical research. The compensation and benefits package offered is on the better side of the average in comparison to most Big 10 Universities, especially in the context of reasonably low living costs.
cons: There have been some recent concerns with the Board of Regents not taking student and faculty concerns into consideration, especially with the hire of New President Bruce Harreld.

job_title: Teaching Assistant in Iowa City, IA
pros: I got a chance to help my student and upgrade my knowledge and there is good environment to all access that help you to teaching and helping students. There is good compensation and it is well ranked university too.
cons: I did not see any bad approach from any leaderships administration. They are really helpful and try their best to equip you with all necessary materials.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Iowa City, IA
pros:
Follows NIH payscale
Able to make own hours
Many available workshops to improve writing, grant applications, etc.
cons:
Promoting diversity is a facade. 
You are put into a quasi-student/employee position that only seems to give you the worst of each position. Want good parking options? That's only for employees. Want childcare options? Employees only, you don't qualify. For insurance, you don't qualify for employee-based insurance (UIChoice), only for student-level insurance (UIGradcare or SHIP), but since you are not a student, it costs $200 a month instead of approx. $25. If you want family coverage, you are looking at upwards of $500 a month.

job_title: Software Engineer in Iowa City, IA
pros: If you have your eyes open, the University of Iowa presents fantastic opportunities to learn. I was able to make real contributions to important projects even as an entry-level programmer, and was able to move into positions requiring ever-more responsibility. I learned a ton, was self-directed much of the time, and was trusted and respected by my managers.
cons: The mood and culture of the workplace seems to vary widely between different colleges and administrative units. I happened to work someplace great, but I heard horror stories about the hospital.

job_title: Research Assistant in Iowa City, IA
pros:
1. Locates in a very nice small town with almost everything you need but quiet and peaceful.
2. Responsible teachers for a lot of courses. Strict TA English program. Department pay international TA's English courses tuition.
3. Interdisciplinary study has been focused. Even PHD needs to take courses from other department (rule of my dept) as a cognate area.
4. Convenient bus system with wifi in bus and arrive time prediction.
cons:
1. Farley inconvenient flight.
2. Though 4-5 h drive to Chicago & Minneapolis, it is still not so close.
3. Some good shopping mall are not locates here.

job_title: Communications Assistant in Iowa City, IA
pros: I received mentorship from "higher ups" and was able to contribute new ideas about how the client experience and website could be improved. My coworkers and employers were very kind and polite, and I never felt as if my "student worker" status hindered me from sharing ideas.
cons: I don't have any cons I can share! I was in one of the medical buildings, so sometimes there would be weird lab scents floating around. Otherwise, everything was awesome.

review_title: Great place to start out at, not a long term career though.
job_title: Police Dispatcher in Iowa City, IA
pros: The benefits are great and the people I work with are awesome. There's also a lot of down time if you have other things to work on (this can also be a con when you don't have anything to do and you get really bored). You can usually work as much or as little overtime as you want.
cons: The salary is much lower than you would get working for a normal city or county dispatch center. The University is also a much slower place to work, there's not nearly as much action as the city gets.

job_title: Facilities/Skilled Trades in Iowa City, IA
pros: Great working environment and productive relationships among co-workers and immediate supervisors in the trenches.
cons: Upper-level administrators are clueless and treat workers poorly.  The UI is developing a reputation for NOT being an employer of choice. Management has no respect for employees.

review_title: Student Research Assistant (National Advanced Driving Simulator)
job_title: Student Research Assistant in Iowa City, IA
pros:
Diversity of roles, anywhere from shredding documents to operating state of the art simulators 
Supervisor doesn't get mad when you make mistakes, instead they instruct you how to improve
Get to interact with a variety of driving simulators
Great place to get experience for undergrads, plus it looks really good on your resume 
Co-workers are super friendly and approachable
cons: There is a lack of hours when in between projects. At times, i have to scrounge for work hours from permanent staff.

review_title: Short term good - long term question
job_title: Visiting Assistant Professor in Iowa City, IA
pros:
Really great benefits - good health insurance, fantastic quality of doctors and providers at the University Hospitals and Clinics.
Pay is ok.
Grad students are unionized, which really helps protect rights, and the union fights for its members.
cons: Battles at leadership and governmental levels make the long term forcast concerning - the University, like so many others across the country, is heading in a clearly business-focused path, which means that professors and instructors are devalued and administrators are over valued.

review_title: Has potential, but falls short on many levels
job_title: Scientist in Iowa City, IA
pros: Health insurance coverage is great.
cons: Dealing with staff in Internal Medicine specifically was very difficult and needlessly time-consuming.  Ex: HR failed to put me in the system in time so I worked my first week for free - they had at least a month notice for my start date. Afterward, I asked about compensation for the week and they could not have cared less.  Very frustrating, unprofessional and unacceptable.

review_title: great place to work if you like teaching or research
job_title: Associate Research Scientist in Iowa City, IA
pros: Academic environment provides challenging scientific projects to work on and intelligent people to interact with. Great benefits.
cons: Somewhat isolated and less career options compared to metro areas. Salaries not very competitive due to the same reason.

job_title: Student IT Support in Iowa City, IA
pros: Management staff at the University of Iowa College of Engineering are excellent.  Very flexible with hours (for the student employees) and it pays well.
cons: I honestly cannot think of any negatives to working here.  Sometime people recognize you as an employee when you are in the lab doing your own work (off the clock) and ask for help, but thats not really a big deal.

job_title: Graduate Student/Graduate Research Assistant in Iowa City, IA
pros: collegial and collaborative atmosphere; highly academic environment without being stuffy; wonderful college town with just enough to do to keep you engaged without creating too many distractions; great cultural opportunities and overall quality of life; compensation far out-paces the cost of living; it is great to work in a community where education is so highly valued
cons: the winters are downright brutal; the undergrad students are a crazy, partying bunch of folks; management is a too hands-off at times;

job_title: Front Desk Clerk in Iowa City, IA
pros: Working in the Hillcrest Dormitory was overall a very positive experience, and I gained a lot of confidence dealing with over 500 students at in multiple circumstances and at all hours of the day and night.
cons: That you have to work the desk in the middle of the night, but that is what you sign up for.  You get in the swing of things eventually.

review_title: All depends on where you work
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Iowa City, IA
pros:
Great benefits package
If you work in the right area, you get to do cool things and help people.  Many good people work here.
cons: Lots of turnover in management right now.  Board of Regents is not positive towards us right now.  Moving toward a business model that is not as employee or student friendly.   If you work in the wrong area you can be totally hosed.

review_title: Good Experience- great part time student job
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Iowa City, IA
pros: Was able to focus on my schoolwork while having a meaningful job.  The people are very friendly and everyone seemed to appreciate us for the most part.
cons: Frequent busy work and asked to do every little thing no one else wanted to do.  Often times the students are blamed for whatever random thing may go wrong that no one else wants to own up to.  That would suck more, but our program has awesome people heading it up that protect us really well from the Clinic Admin or Board.

review_title: Great place to be a grad student, if you have the right advisor
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Iowa City, IA
pros: The salaries in STEM fields are competitive and the tuition fee is waived for full time TAs and RAs. Many benefits are good, for example UIGradCare is a great healthcare plan, but it may be phased out soon after recent Iowa collective bargaining legislation. The interview process (after being accepted to the program) to choose a faculty research advisor takes into consideration both the student and faculty members decisions. If you are placed with a good advisor, your time will go very smoothly, since you have to collaborate on research projects, technical presentations, and publications. Luckily I fell into that category and had a very positive experience.
cons: Affordable housing in Iowa City is becoming increasingly difficult to come by. The atmosphere on campus is changing to seem more profit-driven with graduate students and faculty members teaching more students (increased work loads) without salary/benefits increases. UI Department heads have a lot of power and sometimes use it to the disadvantage of other faculty members and students (appointing TAs, choosing RAs, some financial decisions). If you're placed with a bad advisor, prepare to fight to get your publications read/reviewed, schedule meetings, get funding for technical presentations, solve problems arising between graduate students (who will be first author on a paper, for example), etc.

review_title: Lots of opportunity, lots of red tape
job_title: Administrative Services Specialist in Iowa City, IA
pros:
Great health benefits- better if you are single or dual career- 1 employee plus family can get a little expensive, but still good. 
Lots of professional development opportunities, if you are in the right college/position, there are chances for promotion. 
If you can find a good mentor, there are chances for growth and promotion.  Sometimes you have to move around a bit in order to find a department that will support you. 
As in any place, there are jerks, but also there are incredible people and teams here at the UI and you can find a solid network of professionals that will become your second family.
cons:
Still lots of overly 'traditional' thinkers that DO NOT like change and are terrified of technology. Those people are mostly in charge. Even in 2017,  women are not treated well and mothers might as well just shove off, you will be dismissed and overlooked for promotion- same with people of color. Women in any office are treated as receptionists and secretaries, even if they are directors. Some offices have really stepped up and offered opportunities equally, others are still in the dark ages. Look around when you interview and see which one you are in. 
Also, this is a public university and you will have lots of red tape and oversight. Even though taxes and public support have dwindled to a small percentage of our funding, everything is controlled for whether or not a tax-payer would like it.

review_title: A great institution which  values diversity and creates resources for employees to grow in their careers, and home life.
job_title: Administrative Services Coordinator in Iowa City, IA
pros:
The University of Iowa adds an additional $130.00 to my paycheck each month to help pay for my health insurance.  Because of this, I pay a total of $50.00/month for myself and my 2 children.  This is just one example of the amazing benefits the UI makes available for their employees.  

The diversity efforts on campus are numerous, as many of the colleges, departments, and organizations, have some kind of involvement in a committee or initiative focusing on diversity and how to maintain an inclusive environment for all. This is important to me as a non-white, low-income, single, mother of two.
cons:
The UI is so large, that each department or organization has developed it's own culture and common practices. I was very lucky to land a job in such a forward-thinking, flexible, and trust-worthy organization which values it's employees to the fullest, however, if I were to apply for another position elsewhere at the UI, I would be risking giving up this environment for one that might be a micromanaging nightmare.  

We get paid once a month, which causes me and everyone else I know in a pay grade similar to mine, to be flat broke before the next 1st of the month rolls around.  Also, this really hurts employees when they first start a new job at the UI because they will not get paid until the 1st of the following month.  

The University of Iowa has great transportation options since parking space is extremely limited and expensive downtown and at the hospital.  The cheapest being the $12.00 bus pass, which employees can have deducted from their paycheck each month. The van pool is also convenient for those not living close to a bus route, or even for those living in other towns and cities and will cost a little over $40/month. But...

...as someone who has no option but to drive to work because I require having two child car seats to take my children to daycare each morning and pick them up each afternoon, it is unfortunate that parking is so expensive ($98.00/month for a ramp if you're able to wait months or even YEARS on the wait list, or about $55.00 for a lot that you either walk a very long way to and from, or have to take a shuttle to/from with limited run hours.

review_title: Great part-time job while you're in school.
job_title: Desktop Support Assistant in Iowa City, IA
pros: I worked in the IT department, and it was overall a positive experience. The hours were flexible and everyone that works there is really friendly. Learned quite a bit about IT support and working with people. I got a regular raise in pay, as much as 25 cents per semester.
cons: Sometimes the work is menial, like loading and unloading trucks of equipment. One manager was occasionally condescending, but nice overall.  You'll occasionally have other students that are hard to work with, but that's to be expected in any job.

job_title: Medical Assistant in Iowa City, IA
pros: I am currently employed through the University of Iowa and love working there! I am proud to say that I have been employed at UIHC for over 13 yeaes and have a good rapport with my coworkers and physician's.
cons: Only con is that I have been commuting 146 miles roundtrip from the Quad Cities to Iowa City for over 13 years.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Iowa City, IA
pros: The benefits are one of the pros in my understanding. The health insurance and other discounts are easy to use and can save quite some money. The environment is neat and quiet. Very comfortable to live.
cons: The winter season is obviously too cold. Also in Iowa, you cannot expect a lot of money. But it's fine, the living cost is not high either.

review_title: With UIHC's shift in priorities, my job has gone from awesome to awful
job_title: Nursing Assistant in Iowa City, IA
pros: Good benefits, decent salary, exciting work environment.
cons: Low level support personnel have punitive workloads that border on abusive.  The current governor has declared war on the union and he is seeking to freeze our pay raises and slash our benefits packages, as well as severely restricting our rights to collective bargaining. Employees who leave aren't being replaced, only adding to the burden on support staff.

job_title: Rhetoric TA in Iowa City, IA
pros: Rhetoric is a great department to TA in as there is a lot of professional development. It's also very collegiate and less condescending toward undergrads than other departments.
cons: Rhetoric isn't taken as seriously in the university so a lot of politics which you can generally avoid if you don't want to be a part of it. More of an issue for permanent faculty but there can be trickle down.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Iowa City, IA
pros: I have a lot of freedom in what I do with my time at work. I am able to do some homework on the job, as long as I am completing all other duties.
cons: You have to deal with a lot a lot of people. There are a lot of people who are very unaware about the university and need a lot of assistance.

job_title: Student Advisor in Iowa City, IA
pros: Management is very open to listening to employees. The technology access for employees is very convenient and easy to use. Benefits are excellent!
cons: The winters can be rough, but the city and the university do a very good job of clearing streets and walkways. If you department is very small, it can be difficult to advance.

review_title: Great workplace. Tough to get funding.
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Iowa City, IA
pros: The University of Iowa has a very friendly and collaborative research environment. People are almost always willing to share and help.
cons: If you do not have a grant then job security is very poor. It is difficult to get funding from the department of defense and from the American Cancer Society if you don't live on one the coasts.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Kansas City, MO
pros: The university of Iowa is one of the top research institutes in the country. The Pharmacology department recently underwent remodeling and has swanky new labs with an open-lab setting to encourage collaborations. The administrative staff as well as the researchers are very nice and always willing to help.
cons: Research funding might vary from lab to lab so you might want to make sure you know about that before hand. Iowa is a university town and outside of the school and hospital there aren't too many employment opportunities.

job_title: Information Security Officer in Iowa City, IA
pros: Benefits.  They are very good and help off set the lower salaries.  Environment is nice.  People are friendly.  Allowed to take time off as needed.
cons: The financial situation is going downhill fast.  Salary reductions, job cuts, and unpaid days off make this less of an interesting place to work.

review_title: Good place to work, bad manager
job_title: Manager, Public Relations in Iowa City, IA
pros: Good benefits, committed colleagues. Located in a great place to live. An intellectually stimulating environment. Opportunities for professional development in some departments and units.
cons: Below-market salaries; difficult managers in many departments and units. Not a lot of transparency regarding important decisions and changes. An unfortunate number of disengaged employees across the institution

job_title: Desk Clerk in Iowa City, IA
pros: flexible hours depending on your classes. You can work on homework during your shift once you finish all your tasks. Other co-works are usually really good about switching/ covering shifts when you can not work. If you go home for the summer or study abroad, you can continue working the following semester
cons: You start out at a low pay and yearly raises are next to nothing. Overnight shift is required. Weekend shift is also required. You might also have to work over Thanksgiving or spring break.

review_title: I am very happy with my experience as an RA and the relationships I developed with my residents, staff and management.
job_title: Resident Assistant in Iowa City, IA
pros: The benefits of being an RA at Iowa are unheard of elsewhere and if you have a personality that fits the job well it is easy to put in the time that being an RA requires.
cons: If you are really interested in changing the way things are done and being extremely innovative this might not be the job for you. The status quo is valued at Iowa.

review_title: Very nice people to work with
job_title: Research Assistant in Iowa City, IA
pros:
I worked as a Research Assistant in Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering. People are very nice and collaborate with each other (both within the CEE department and other research group on campus) on projects. 
The health insurance is very good (for UI Grad Care, it is only about 25 dollars, including dental care) and we have the wonderful Iowa hospital and clinics.
cons: Winter is long. But the response system is very good, cambus and road condition will be quickly restored.

review_title: Satisfying and fulfilling place to work, allows for networking and meeting many wonderful people.
job_title: Patient Service Specialist in Iowa City, IA
pros: Friendly staff, great work atmosphere, patients/customers help to make each day special and eventful, plenty of challenges to keep motivated. Near impossible to come to work without a smile.
cons: Salary is only marginally better than new people entering the position, even after many years in the position and despite good reviews.

review_title: Horrible- Great recruiting bonus yet excessive overworking of graduate student labor
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Iowa City, IA
pros: There's some great people who work in the chemistry department. Seek them out and you may have a good experience at this place.
cons: Corrupted chemistry department- you may be asked to 'make the average grade come out to an A' if you TA. University regulations require TAs to work a maximum of 20 hours per week on top of their class and research load, but you'll work much, much more than that due to abuse of the system. Don't like it? You won't get your degree. That's how it works. Stay away- there are much better departments out there.

review_title: Working in IT at University of Iowa
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Iowa City, IA
pros: Get to know and use different technologies
cons:
Some IT departments are managed by non technical personnel who have no clue what a technology does, its pros and cons. Who keep pushing to do things fast. Giving less time to code, there is no structured team, like business analyst, testers.
No documentation for any software.

review_title: I had a great time and learned a lot about teaching and leadership
job_title: Undergraduate Teaching Assistant in Iowa City, IA
pros:
-High compensation for undergraduate
-Allowed to be very independent in work flow
-Are able to maintain a very flexible work schedule
-Have the opportunity to lead or follow as much as desired
cons: -Course plans/schedules can often switch at the last minute or loose ends will take too long to be tied up. This has taught me a lot about organization and creating a documents to assist following groups.

review_title: Experience depends on department, mountains of bureaucracy
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Iowa City, IA
pros: Good health care and dental benefits, organized graduate student union (COGS)
cons: Treated like a student or employee whenever it's most convenient for the administration. Nickel and dimed out of student fees, particularly in regards to graduation and dissertation submission. The 20 hour per week labor contract is routinely broken, as graduate research blurs with student credits. Vague or nonexistent itemization of fees.

job_title: Senior Systems Administrator in Iowa City, IA
pros: Love what I do, but my boss is over bearing and gets the slightest bit upset if I show any initiative.  Most people generally care about the institution ahead of their employment.
cons: Getting into a good department with competent people is a crap shoot.  No one comes to work here for the money.  I'm rarely allowed to learn from failure.

job_title: in Iowa City, IA
pros: Experienced staff members who really care about the work and really know what they are doing. Staff members are loyal to the center and continue to work there for years on end.
cons: Poor management with an ever changing agency. A brand new executive director who needed to receive more training has had a difficult transition.

job_title: Athletic Facilities Student Worker in Iowa City, IA
pros: Simple work, easy to work around schedule, work with other students, good supervisors. There is plenty of down time to get homework done, schedules are given out for the month a week and a half beforehand. There is free admission to all sporting events except football games. You get to see the inside workings of Iowa Athletics.
cons: Some jobs can be very labor intensive. Some people will have to work during sporting events.

review_title: The experience at the University of Iowa has been great.
job_title: Clerk in Iowa City, IA
pros: I really enjoy working for the University Parking Office because they are very flexible with my class schedule.  It's allowed me to gain a lot of experience in customer service and helped me build my problem solving skills.
cons: This department is currently short staffed so there are a lot more projects and tasks that are having to be completed out by inexperienced staff.  The majority of the full-time staff is not helpful.

job_title: in Iowa City, IA
pros:
Opportunities to participate in lots of activities
Overall Benefits are good 
Opportunities to explore and offer new ideas
cons: Needs improvement for communication across the campuses and within the college, amongst staff and faculty...

job_title: Graduate Student in Iowa City, IA
pros: Great research environment with access to many knowledgeable professors and industry representatives.  Be sure to find the right supervisor who has been around awhile
cons: The classes are relatively easier but focus on the mechanical engineering dept, they are the best and most useful.   Some BME classes are good but most are a waste of time.

job_title: Customer Service in Iowa City, IA
pros: The benefits are amazing, UIHC really takes care of their employees. Paid vacation and sick days, amazing insurance, discounted gym memberships, retirement...
cons: From what I've heard, there is a 3 year waitlist for parking.

job_title: in Iowa City, IA
pros: Great academic atmosphere, wonderful support from the university in terms of research funding, and a really nice place to live.  I highly recommend it to other people.
cons: Iowa City is a small place if you are not comfortable living in the Midwest.  The benefits are a little cheap as well.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Iowa City, IA
pros: Get paid while obtaining a Masters or Doctoral degree
cons: At times it can be stressful to deal with professor's egos and move through the many hurdles. That is true of every university though. It's hard to consider this a place where career advancement can take place from the student to the professor level since it would be hard to ever be considered a colleague by people that used to be your professors. You will always be considered a student.

job_title: Systems Administrator in Iowa City, IA
pros:
Depending on your boss it's low stress, easy work. 

Pay is decent,  benefits are very good.
cons:
Not a lot of room for regular employees to innovate,  only the "chosen ones" by management can introduce changes

Subpar learning environment for a college

Raises are pretty small and bad employees get the same as the good

job_title: Head Teaching Assistant in Cedar Rapids, IA
pros: Opportunity to learn a lot every day. Get to know the professors better. Good job to put on a resume.
cons: Can be difficult to complete tasks and there is not likely going to be a lot of help provided as the work is new and no one else knows how to do it.

review_title: I had good experience with UI.
job_title: in Iowa City, IA
pros: Professors and students are very nice and smart. The housing price is very low compared to a lot of other places.
cons: Most of time you got to be in the home or in the office. Otherwise, there are no too many other thing you can do.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Iowa City, IA

*Chill work environment
*Great front office people
cons:

review_title: I loved working with the faculty and doing research.
job_title: Research Assistant in Iowa City, IA

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Iowa City, IA

- learned a lot about food prep

- free food

- didn't get schedule for Tuesday until Sunday

review_title: student research assistant in university of iowa
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Iowa City, IA
pros: good connection with the academic world, professors are keen on working with projects and are patient and helpful when advising you
cons: there are less opportunities to connect to other academic communities at the national and international level. feel a little bit  isolated as many projects are within the regional or local extent

job_title: Research Assistant in Iowa City, IA
pros: Good benefits and health insurance. Small town that never has traffic problem. People are nice. Relatively good Chinese food among small towns.
cons: Salary is somehow low. Far from big cities - 3.5 hours drive to Chicago. Kind of boring if you come from a really big city.

job_title: Research Assistant in Iowa City, IA
pros:
Lots of available jobs.
Lots of possible work experience.
cons:
Many of the available jobs are grueling, inflexible to schedules and more than likely not applicable to your program of study what so ever. 
Many of the jobs are horribly under paid- minim wage here being lower than the rest of the county.
Many of the managers are unbearable, insufferable, and inflexible.

job_title: in Iowa City, IA
pros: Great group of people to work with, very diverse in educational and cultural experiences.  Dedicated to the advancement of scientific knowledge.
cons: In terms of financial renumeration there is a large gap between what one would make in industry versus what one makes in academia.  But this is evident anywhere.

review_title: It is a great experience, very liberal and friendly place to work at.
job_title: in Iowa City, IA
pros: The University offers great benefits and is located in a very nice town where you can balance your work, health and family life.
cons: It is located in the deep Midwest and sometimes it is hard to transfer from Iowa city to another town.

review_title: Loved working here, this is a great place to work during college
job_title: Assistant Service Technician in Iowa City, IA
pros: The training process was easy, the city is great it has a great environment. They give you off for breaks too which is one of my favorite things because you get to visit family for thanksgiving and christmas.
cons: It is horribly cold in the winter along with super icy every where you go because they use sand to get rid of it and not salt.

review_title: Good place for pursuing a PhD, bad for life
job_title: Graduate Student in Iowa City, IA
pros: UI provides a flexible environment for research and PhD program. Funding is sufficient and projects are enough, good place for PhD
cons: average low ranking of ME program, our group purely depends on the advisor's reputation in academia community, weak competition compared with other Big-10s.

job_title: Graduate Assistant in Iowa City, IA
pros: Professional work culture, and great benefits as a Graduate Assistant. My bosses were not overbearing, and were very understanding in case of personal difficulties. The tuition reduction is good, and health insurance is very subsidized, as well as dental insurance. I gained good teaching experience which will be useful to me in the future.
cons: None that can be thought of.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Iowa City, IA
pros:
University has a very good campus and people are very humble.
As an employee I am very satisfied working here.
cons: Some policies can result in employee dissatisfaction, but groups such as COGS are always upto challenge those and help employees get what they are entitled to.

job_title: Research Assistant II in Iowa City, IA
pros: Great minds -- great research, generally pleasant culture with lots of perks including excellent 401K, paid time off
cons: mediocrity rules in academic research. some investigators can create difficult work environments and employees sometimes do not have a voice. After 7 years of work or so had hit the ceiling in my career.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Iowa City, IA
pros: The university offers competitive compensation for the area's low cost of living. Colleagues are very open to collaboration across divisions and departments.
cons: It can be very difficult to get to work, especially in inclement weather, due to significant lack of parking and limited public transit options. Limited and poor dining options on west campus.

review_title: University of Iowa is a great place to work. It provides a lot of opportunities to grow and attain good knowledge.
job_title: in Iowa City, IA
pros: It has a lot of research opportunities and hence also lot of support to engineering and technology careers
cons: Its ranking is a bit low, it has the capability to become a top school but still its not utiilizing that.

review_title: Alumni working for your alma matter
job_title: Admissions Visitor Center in Iowa City, IA
pros: Excellent people who are willing to work with you and help you learn, intelligent professionals who are hard working and carry with them a great work ethic above that of many other areas in the U.S. but also maintaining a work-life balance that spans across companies/jobs/people.
cons: Small professional network outside of the Midwest

job_title: Transportation Operater in Iowa City, IA
pros: Very flexible management with good starting pay. The sense of community involvement is extremely high. Surrounded by supportive peers and management. True appreciation of your work by community.
cons: Pay is lower than at other employers but this must be balanced with very reasonable cost of living. Some jobs can be very dependent on office politics, and some of the resources are being wastefully used.

job_title: Student Instructional Technology Assistant in Iowa City, IA
pros:
-Really enjoyed working with high-performing faculty and staff

-Great people on my team
-Management didn't waste my time
cons:
-The (ever-changing) bureaucracy of the ITS department was challenging to navigate at times
-At times, the absence of direction was frustrating

job_title: Associate Research Scientist in Iowa City, IA
pros:
Lots of vacation time
Encouraging of staff to take up projects outside of work
Entreprenurial resources available to all
Some tuition assistance available
Excellent health care
Excellent retirement benefits
Access to all University's educational resources
Immigration help
cons:
If your supervisor does not want you to grow you are stuck
Remuneration less than peers in private sector
Complete lack of growth

review_title: Engineer at the Univ. of Iowa
job_title: Engineer III in Iowa City, IA
pros: Great retirement and vacation benefits, access to top-quality health care, flexible work schedule, diverse workforce, opportunities for professional development, friendly environment
cons: Large organization overall can make you feel lost or unimportant when dealing with benefits or other offices outside your immediate department.

job_title: Supply Chain Specialist in Iowa City, IA
pros: The benefits are wonderful.  I'm part of building a new Org and helped implement processes.  I have supportive co-workers.
cons: There are too many people involved in processes.  This is a hierarchical platform to work with which limits efficiency and effectiveness, at times.

job_title: in Iowa City, IA
pros: Innovative work opportunities, Excellent compensation, I have had the best time working here with a talented group of people and work environment that allows to follow your own ideas
cons: Iowa city is very gloomy and lonely city with not much of fun activities, becomes harder in winter season especially

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Iowa City, IA
pros: Fairly good pay for the amount of work expected, lots of freedom of when you prepare for classes, and can often prepare own agendas
cons: Don't always get to work with the best professors, which makes the job difficult at times. Often told exactly what to do, so there is not a lot of room for creativity. Salary is good for part-time, but not necessarily enough to pay the bills

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Iowa City, IA
pros: As a graduate research assistant, the benefit is pretty good, health & dental insurance are very good. Especially if you work for hospital, in addition to the tuition, the miscellaneous fees will also be paid. Consider the low living cost in the mid west, UI is pretty awesome to be considered to work for!
cons: You don't have much choice to negotiate with employer about the salary

review_title: Could be better. Could be worse.
job_title: IT Specialist in Iowa City, IA
pros: They don't completely screw you over. Moderate pay. Some benefits, though don't expect much. Access to a lot of student discounts with your .edu address.
cons: Benefits lacking. Senior management repeatedly given votes of no confidence. CEO had mistakes on his resume and wildly overpaid. Clearly corrupt board of regents. Unimpressive overall.

job_title: Teaching Assistant in Monee, IL
pros: Flexible schedule that enables students to gain research experience while also attending school.  Also have the chances of getting paid
cons: Depending on who you work for it can be slow sometimes.  I have found times in where I had free time and wanted to work yet had nothing to do.

job_title: Lab Assistant in Iowa City, IA
pros: Surrounding yourself with some of the brightest people in the country. The work can seem boring at times but then you get to see some pretty remarkable things. Makes for a great resume building if you do the work.
cons: You could probably make more working somewhere else but if you are more worried about your future than your paycheck this is worth it.

review_title: Decent pay and treatment of TA
job_title: Teaching Assistant in Iowa City, IA
pros: Good benefits. Graduate student/TA's are unionized. Semester fees were around $450. Tuition was 100% waved. TAship required you to work 20 hours a week. Great medical insurance for single individuals. Some married TA's complained that those benefits didn't easily extend to their families.
cons: I heard horror stories of TAs working for professors who treated them poorly and overworked them. That was not my experience.

job_title: Engineer in Iowa City, IA
pros: benefits are better than most other companies - 8% retirement match, great health care, 6weeks paid vacation after working 5years there)
cons: limited career path, poor management skills for upper level management, lots of bureaucracy and politicking, slackers cannot be fired, overachievers cannot be rewarded

review_title: Great growth opportunities for students in many different positions
job_title: Resident Assistant in Iowa City, IA
pros:
Most positions offer competitive pay and/or great benefits.
Iowa City is an amazing place to live and work.
Networking opportunities are always available and people want to help you succeed.
cons: Being a public/government institution, there are always bureaucratic hoops to jump through to get approval for anything. A million people have to sign off on something as simple as a mass email.

job_title: Software Developer in Iowa City, IA
pros: You don't have to work particularly hard and rarely does anyone get let go.
cons: There's not much upward mobility. Pretty much the only way to get a promotion or a significant pay raise is to get a job offer from another company. Management is much more political than effective.

job_title: Marketer in Iowa City, IA
pros:
Flexible Scheduling for Students
Real-world Professional Development
Friendly Work Environment
Access to Professional Tools and Software
Networking Opportunities
