Some filing and information systems were antiquated
Little training was given to new employees

review_title: University of Iowa Food Worker - Hillcrest Marketplace.
job_title: Food Worker in Iowa City, IA
pros: Excellent benefits, good pay, MOST of the students are a joy to work with
cons: You only get paid once a month, extremely hard to get a job here, and very high expectations during probationary period. Some standards are almost impossible to meet.

review_title: An Information Institution with an Institutional Policy Against Making Information Available
job_title: Curator Librarian in Iowa City, IA
pros: Health care is paid for and prescriptions are free
cons: Policy of internal hires, low morale, territorial behaviors, cataloging backlogs, low budget, workplace culture of "doing more with less", hostility, insecurities, underqualified people in management positions

job_title: Parking Coordinator/Cashier Coordinator in Iowa City, IA
pros: They provided a great wage for the work that you do. There is downtime during the job so that you can work on your coursework.
cons: Sometimes it might be hard to get a shift off, although if you really needed to they are pretty lenient on just letting you take the shift off instead of making you work or getting it switched.

review_title: Great place to work and go to school
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Iowa City, IA
pros: Good staff and great facilities. If you have to live in the Midwest, you would do well to be in Iowa City and working for UI.
cons: School still seems stuck in a different time. Not entirely, but it is an understandable shock to come and work here after living on the left coast.

job_title: Student IT Technician in Iowa City, IA
pros: This job (Student IT Support for the Housing & Dining department) has great job security and provides very good compensation for a student university job. You'll learn a lot of skills on the job (problem solving, trouble shooting, working together, prioritizing tasks, etc.) and it looks great on a resume.
cons: For being a part-time job for students I can't think of any cons.

job_title: Intern in Iowa City, IA
pros: Professors provide both immediate and long-term career support and mentorship. Work hard to make the experience the best it can be.
cons: Very minor: all internship stipends come monthly at the end of the month, which can make relocation difficult for students.

job_title: Receptionist in Iowa City, IA
pros: I love the University of Iowa because there is a lot of holiday vacation and PTO. Also great benefits and great people to work with.
cons: Parking is tricky and often you have to take the bus to work.

review_title: One of the most amazing adventures of my life: the people I have met, and the things that I have learned.
job_title: Student Office Worker/Ambassador in Iowa City, IA
pros: The most amazing people that I work with, awesome work environment and camaraderie around the office.
cons: Constantly being on campus after a long day at school or long nights studying.

review_title: Working for this University kept me afloat during college
job_title: ITS Receptionist in Iowa City, IA
pros: In college it is important to have a balance between work, school, and your social life. Luckily, here they are generous and flexible with hours and taking time off.
cons: Of course nothing is perfect, unfortunately the pay is weak. But that is expected at this level of job.

review_title: Good compensation and cause, awkward culture
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Iowa City, IA
pros: Compensation packages tend to be generous for permanent hires. Environment is intellectually and socially stimulating.
cons: Organization is bureaucratic and slow to move. Wide range of performance is tolerated, from full engagement to phoning it it. Leadership is always on the defensive.

job_title: Assistant Research Scientist in Iowa City, IA
pros: Good benefits and nice work environment. Personnel can interact with diverse people, that interaction enriches the work force.
cons: Scientific Research organization does not allow growing as you would desire. The university allow medical doctors to do basic scientific research even they are not well qualified to do that.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Iowa City, IA
pros: Great mentors that really help to take your career to the next level.  This is a very collaborative environment.
cons: Not very many grad assistantships and they are hard to come by.  It can be difficult to gain a lot of meaningful experience if you're not intentional about it.

job_title: Coach in Iowa City, IA
pros: You will be surrounded with a community of intelligent Phds, some doing very interesting work in their respective fields, a super fan sport scene, and a safe and easy town to live in. Great benefits and healthcare!
cons: People stay forever, and the culture of complacency and being average is the norm in most parts of the University. Students are about the same.

review_title: Brief review of the University of Iowa
job_title: Graduate Student in Iowa City, IA
pros:
Interesting research projects
Good people in the department
A very nice place to live
cons:
Rapidly neoliberalizing state and institution
University community and community at large are lacking in many kinds of diversity
Not as many social attractions as in a large city

job_title: Support Services in Iowa City, IA
pros: Good health insurance & good amount of vacation/sick leave.
cons: Work well over 40hrs/week. Show no appreciation for laborer type jobs. Salaries suck unless you are married & your spouse works for them as well. Bad place to work if you are an actual single parent. They seem to reward the lazy, dumb, & self absorbed. Theres no benefit to being a loyal long term employee.

job_title: in Iowa City, IA
pros: There is a great group of people in my department to work with.  Good hours and benefits.  In research, we have a great population of volunteer participants
cons: The parking is not ideal.  The supervisors need to do a better job of knowing how the clinic works.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Iowa City, IA
pros: Excellent colleagues, good if rather expensive healthcare
cons: TAship salary not livable if you don't study in the college of arts and sciences. Additionally, the undergraduate culture is not particularly academic, which means that TAs must deal with highly disinterested students.

review_title: Good place to work with good people and gain some professional skills.
job_title: Resident Assistant in Iowa City, IA
pros: Room and board paid, fast-paced, always interesting, challenging. Pretty complete training and one-on-one support from management. You get to live and work with students, which is both rewarding and frustrating.
cons: Sometimes job requirements get in the way of completing schoolwork. As stated above, you live at your workplace, which can be frustrating.

review_title: The good and the bad of working at a public university
job_title: Senior Applications Developer in Iowa City, IA
pros: Great benefits. Decent pay. My department did try to be progressive, but when interfacing with internal clients, who push back on change, it's hard to keep on the forefront of things.
cons: Lots of red tape. Lots of meetings to make decisions. Many people wishing to keep doing things they way they have always been.

job_title: Research Assistant in Iowa City, IA
pros: Very good plasma physics groups. Plasma physics at Uiowa is one of the best in USA. You do really good research and have collaborations with the best in the world.
cons: You need to work hard to meet your goals, and that is not a con. Cannot think of any cons. You have to do your work fast and publish.

job_title: Security Officer in Iowa City, IA
pros: You cannot get better benefits than the U offers. Even minimum wage employees are covered under the union, and they have a great contract. Benefits outweighs any cons IMO.
cons: If you have an issue, it's often very difficult to figure out who needs to be informed. The university is basically a mini city, and paperwork moves slowly.

job_title: Marketing Representative in Iowa City, IA
pros: This job has given me so much knowledge about working with real life clients and what it would be like to work as an Account Manager in a full time agency.
cons: It is required that you are a student and it is a job that requires a lot of work on top of the school work you must attend to.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Iowa City, IA
pros: Great benefits package, competitive pay, pleasant work environment.  I think the University of Iowa is an excellent employer that tries to keep the interests of the patients and employees in mind.  Many different shifts to choose from, and longevity is rewarded.
cons: There are lots of work politics, many shifts require weekends and / or holidays.

review_title: Enjoyable environment while pay was low
job_title: Senior Applications Developer in Iowa City, IA
pros: Very nice environment to work. People are respectful and generally supportive. Benefits are very good with 2 days of vacation and one and half day of sick leave per month. Work is easy.
cons: pay was low. no that much chance to get professionally trained. life in iowa city is kind of bored even there are lots activities.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Iowa City, IA
pros: Working as a student at the University of Iowa was a great experience. Obviously they are extremely attentive to the needs of student workers. But what students may not realize is how crucial an opportunity it is to work for the University in order to expand your network during and after graduation.
cons: Working over Winter and Spring Breaks.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Iowa City, IA
pros: good environment, great salary paid, good holiday policy, nice persons and many opportunities for future work, and free time schedule
cons: the city here is a little boring compared to big cities, and it is not convenient for people who do not have a car to live here

review_title: Best employer I have worked for
job_title: Program Director in Iowa City, IA
pros: Environment fosters use of knowledge and skills while allowing independence and creativity. As a staff level employee was treated with respect and valued for contributions. Great benefits!
cons: The Iowa Board of Regents determine salary ranges which can limited an individual's negotiation opportunity when being hired. Typically receive a cost of living increase in annual basis.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Iowa City, IA
pros: Pays well, offers flexibility, learn alot about academia.
cons: Many weeks you are working over you appointment allocation with no pay increase.  Often professors won't have material solidified and you are left scrambling to ensure students recieve quality information.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Iowa City, IA
pros: Best benefits package/total comp available, work-life balance, flexibility, opportunity to move within UI, progressive, diverse.
cons: Very liberal campus culture, decentralized depts can skew opinions, large so can be hard to get communication out.

review_title: Really depends on the department you're in
job_title: Research Assistant in Iowa City, IA
pros: Great benefits and working environment, most people are friendly, campus is pretty and the town has all the things you would need
cons: Not much incentive for working hard as there is not much room for quick advancement. I think the expectation is that a person will be there for decades, gradually working their way up

job_title: Librarian in Iowa City, IA
pros: Nothing. Maybe the special collections.
cons: Employees 'higher up' the food chain are always right. Very poor management. UI, and that means the town itself, is hostile to foreigners.  Meagre payment whereas 'functionaries' with not more than a master's degree get several times more. A hierarchical structure similar to companies in the 1970ies. Not open to innovation or initiative; eventually, I will leave based on my own wish. In summary, a "US Midwest Club." My advice: stay away.

job_title: Assistant Research Scientist in Iowa City, IA
pros: Good benefits, quiet place to live, no traffic, easy access to various facilities, low living cost
cons: cold weather, long winter, more opportunities to be provided for professional development

job_title: Research Assistant III in Iowa City, IA
pros:
Great benefits
Collegiate environment
lots of paid time off
Iowa city is very convenient place to live in
Immigration benefits- no problems with foriegn workers making it a very diverse place to work in
cons:
no growth
Lots of cradle to grave dinosaur workers
Low pay compared to the surrounding employees in the region

job_title: Research Assistant in Iowa City, IA
pros: A great environment, always progressing and striving to get better and build research.
cons: Academia cannot compete with industry salaries. Unless you are training or transitioning it is not wise to work in academia for a long time outside of professor/PI/MD roles.

job_title: IT Analyst in Iowa City, IA
pros: Is a great place to work. The work is fun and challenging and the benefits are top notch.
cons: There really is nothing to say the place is great to work at and the benefits top notch.

job_title: Sales Coordinator in Iowa City, IA
pros: Wonderful benefits and 401K match!! 5 weeks of paid vacation! Really the best benefits package of any place I’ve ever worked. I like the culture of the University and people were great.
cons: Not a lot of advancement opportunities and the salary was lower than most other companies, but the benefits somewhat outweighs that.

review_title: IMU Marketing + Design Great Learning Experience
job_title: Student Graphic Designer in Iowa City, IA
pros: The pro-staff genuinely wants students to learn, so the environment if friendly and encouraging. The office is set up like an agency, so it prepares you for real world jobs.
cons: Hourly wages are just above minimum wage

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Iowa City, IA
pros: The Alumni Association and UI Foundation are a great place for students to work. They are flexible with hours, only expect you to work during the week, and the people couldn't be any nicer.
cons: The jobs for students can get pretty boring, but they are still much better than other jobs that students usually get.

job_title: Teaching Assistant in Iowa City, IA
pros:
Nice and calm city,people are amicable and free bus service for the university and mall
nice food and community nearby
cons: Lots of snow in the state, Some time more work is taken from lab TA like lab cleaning and equipment cleaning which is not what grad student should do

job_title: Facility Supervisor in Iowa City, IA
pros: Fun work environment. Good amount of responsibility. Amazing coworkers made it fun to go to work each and every day.
cons: Having to work at 5 in the morning got old fast, but I was the only one doing so every day.

review_title: Great place to work, everyone is understanding and helpful
job_title: Research Assistant in Iowa City, IA
pros: The University of Iowa pays students very well for the work that they do.  With so many employees, everything is conveniently streamlined when you begin.
cons: None, my experience at the U of I was great.  I have no complaints after working there for two years.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Iowa City, IA
pros:
On average, kept hours at about 20
Professor was very helpful 
Didn't have to create discussion outlines from scratch 
Students were generally interested, bright and engaged
cons:
Hours can be very early 
Not all of it's very fun, grading is of course very repetitive 
Of course, some discussion sections are more well behaved than others

job_title: Student Staff in Iowa City, IA
pros: A great way to learn office and professional communication skills. Supervisors are very nice, flexible, and fair.
cons: The job can be stressful if you don't have great people skills or aren't patient on the phone -- many angry or confused parents will call to have us help them figure out their billing issues

job_title: Applications Developer in Iowa City, IA
pros:
Good Benefits, co - workers.
Support from management
Good feedback from employees and employers as to how you are doing
cons:
Limited in technology, can be clicky.
Need better communication between departments sometimes.
Need to look forward and to private sector influence

review_title: Assistant in the Tippie College of Business
job_title: Clerical in Iowa City, IA

cons: There isn't much guidance, and often times its unclear what your job duties are.

job_title: Academic Advisor in Iowa City, IA
pros: A large university with good benefits. Friendly people, and a good place to work long term.
cons: Salaries aren't great, but probably vary depending on the department that you work in.

job_title: Bionic/Special Accommodation Transport Operator in Iowa City, IA
pros: Make your own schedule, flexible hours, highest pay for students on campus, and easy to schedule time off.
cons: Required to work at least 14 hours each week regardless of semester hours or previous obligations.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Iowa City, IA
pros: Most of the Professors are very understanding and helping. Good pay for a student job, covers health insurance and most of the tution. Not allot of pressure like other graduate assistant jobs.
cons: Overall for this job, I think CS Department is pretty nice and cool. More work load in the finals week.

review_title: Great place to work for students
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Iowa City, IA
pros: Excellent pay.  Great work environment.  Surrounded by great people who are understanding of the student life and willing to work with your schedule.
cons: I can not think of any off the top of my head.  This was an all around great experience for me.

job_title: Cambus Driver in Iowa City, IA

-Flexible Schedule
-Raises every 6 months based on Merit
-Relaxed and open environment
-Corner office and 400,000 company car

-Student Run so some deficiencies when working around school schedules
-Habitually understaffed, however this opens up opportunity for working more and making extra money

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Iowa City, IA

review_title: Great part time job for college student
job_title: Finance Assistant in Iowa City, IA

cons: If you enjoy cubicles, work gossip than you'll love this job. Personally I can't stand that type of work environment. Also good luck trying to do anything creative.

review_title: Wonderful place to work and love my job.
job_title: Human Resources Coordinator in Iowa City, IA
pros: There are lots of opportunities within the University or Hospitals and Clinics and the University is very supportive of finding the best role for each person and utilizing existing talent.
cons: Being very large, there is always a lot to learn about how things work.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Iowa City, IA
pros: The humanities programs at Iowa are decent, Iowa City has a lot of culture for a small town, and graduate student compensation is pretty good.
cons: It's graduate school. You work long hours for relatively little thanks or credit. Classes and research leave little time to work outside of a TAship or RAship.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Iowa City, IA
pros: It is a large school so there is a lot of opportunity and potential for growth.   Lots of good resources and other teachers to interact with.
cons: I would like if it was more cohesive, I worked in the business building so there was lots of different ideas.

job_title: Assistant Professor in Iowa City, IA

cons: There can be too much administration that oversees departments which can be good in terms of preventing disasters but bad because they are micro managed

review_title: It was OK for during college.
job_title: Student Library Assistant in Iowa City, IA

job_title: Lead Desk Clerk in Iowa City, IA

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Iowa City, IA

cons: located in small town; less diverse culture; less competing working environment; comparably hard to find a local job in research fields.

review_title: I have been here for the past two months. So far satisfied.
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Iowa City, IA
pros: It is a world renowned school for graduate studies.
cons: Iowa city does not have many places of interest. Life can sometimes get dull as I am not a very party person.

review_title: Great for Students Who Need Money
job_title: Desk Clerk in Iowa City, IA

cons: If you are working a student job, you're only allowed to work up to 20 hours a week. If a student employee, you're starting pay is below the Johnson County minimum.

job_title: in New York, NY
pros: I was very blessed to have the opportunity working with a very passionate and caring team when I was at Iowa. They really demonstrated what student support in a higher education institution should look like.

review_title: Great place to work, friendly environment
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Iowa City, IA

review_title: This is the perfect student job
job_title: ITS Student Analyst in Iowa City, IA

job_title: Office Assistant in Iowa City, IA

review_title: Great place to work! Few opportunities for advancement.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Iowa City, IA

job_title: Core Facility Manager in Iowa City, IA

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Iowa City, IA

review_title: I worked as an undergraduate TA in the college of engineering
job_title: Undergraduate Teaching Assistant in Iowa City, IA

job_title: Research Assistant in Iowa City, IA

review_title: Swim Instructor at Campus Recreation and Wellness Center
job_title: Swim Teacher in Iowa City, IA

review_title: A great place for students to earn extra cash
job_title: Retail Associate in Iowa City, IA

job_title: Graduate Student in Iowa City, IA

review_title: Great Part-time Job while in School
